Agency Project Name: Renovation of Anna M. Kross Center (AMKC)  at Rikers Island
Agency Project Description: Gut renovation of existing Officers lockers and toilet and shower facilities to provide new lockers, new fixtures and interior finishes including lighting and renovated HVAC systems and other items as needed.  The flowing Officer and Senior Officer Locker Rooms will be renovated: • Locker Room Type         • Male Officer   • Female Officer               • Sr. Male Officer             • Sr. Female Officer         • Male Dep Warden         • Female Dep Warden                                                     Furthermore, the following work types have been identified:• New Lockers• Replace existing wall, floor and ceiling finishes.      • Renovate finishes in Toilet Shower Areas• Replace Plumbing Fixtures and Toilet Accessories• Replace lighting throughout with LED lighting• Renovate Ventilation/HVAC system  Justification: It was  determined that the current structures, and infrastructure that supports the buildings, located on Rikers Island requires immediate renovations and rehabilitation, and without any design and construction solutions, these structures will continue to endanger the health of the occupants.  This critical and necessary work is needed immediately to provide a safe, clean environment on Rikers Island. The renovation work proposed for the  Anna M. Kross Center (AMKC), is to address the deplorable locker room condition at this facility. The Locker room is in dire need of renovation and is long overdue. This renovation will offer a better working environment for officers which may also improve the officers moral.

Agency Project Description: Demolish existing on-story facility. Construct a two-story new building for animal care center with a drive-through parking lot to meet the new program.

FMS Project Name: Bronx Animal Care Center and Veterinary Clinic
Agency Project Description: Bronx Animal Care Center & Veterinary Clinic is a new 50,000 SF facility that will be housing admissions, adoptions, medical services, and boarding for approximately 70 dogs, 140 cats, 30 rabbits and other species to be determined. Support spaces will include spaces focused on animal caretakers & visitors including offices, restrooms, storage & areas of respite. Integrated with the architecture, the open areas on the site will include a visitor entrance plaza, courtyards to facilitate animal adoptions, enrichment & training spaces for animals, and parking for staff, visitors, and animal transportation vehicles, as well as site lighting and low-maintenance native planting throughout. In addition to the animal housing, the Bronx Animal Care Center will include a community space for academic partnership for youth and enhanced senior services. The building and associated landscape are to achieve LEED Silver standards or higher.

Agency Project Description: his project will enhance pedestrian safety and improve pedestrian circulation by constructing curb extensions, bus bulbs, missing sidewalks, and median tip extensions along Astoria Boulevard, as well as create left turn bays and crosswalks. These interventions will increase pedestrian safety, reduce conflicts between pedestrians, cars, and bikes, and improve pedestrian circulation. In addition, the capital improvements will build on the successes of the operational improvements DOT implemented within these project limits in 2016. The interventions listed below, when implemented together, will make meaningful strides towards permanent safety enhancements along this dangerous corridor in Queens. Agency Project Description: This Vision Zero capital project will construct pedestrian safety-focused geometric improvements at threeintersections in the southern Bronx. The project scope includes two bus bulbs on Westchester Avenue below the Prospect Avenue 2/5 subway station, four additional curb extensions, and streetscape improvements. All three locations in this capital project have received successful operational treatments introduced via StreetImprovement Projects (SIPs). Capital construction will permanently improve safety conditions at theseintersections for all street users by shortening crossing distances, calming traffic, increasing pedestrian visibility, and controlling vehicle turning movements.

FMS Project Name: Pratt Ave Reconstruction and Retaining Wall, SEX20049
Agency Project Name: Pratt Avenue Retaining Wall and Roadway Recon
Agency Project Description: The retaining wall along the segment of Pratt Avenue (Needham Ave to Dead End) shows multiple signs of damage. This includes cracking (long cracks run the entire height of the wall) and movement of the individual elements of the wall. The cracks and movement of the wall has allowed the backfill that supports the roadway to escape. The roadway within the project limits has experienced significant damage due to settlement of supporting materials. The proposed scope includes reconstruction of the roadway and retaining wall along this segment.

Agency Project Name: Snug Harbor Center CTR.1000 Richmond Ter.HVAC/PLU
Agency Project Description: C. MAJOR DESIGN CONSIDERATIONS1. When surveying existing conditions, special attention will be paid to current building loads, layouts, and resulting possible changes in power requirements.2. The existing chilling plant is composed of one chiller installed in approximately 1982, while one other large chiller and one small chiller are not functional. Mechanical equipment and distribution system was designed and specified as per requirement of more than 30 years ago. The centralized cooling equipment (chillers) located in Building L serve 5 other buildings – Buildings M, R, S, T & G (other buildings on site either have their own air conditioning system or use window units).3. In future phase, the Main Hall/Building C Newhouse Center for Contemporary Art and Building B-SIM Natural Sciences Collection which presently do not have any central air- conditioning system will be connected to the central cooling plant. Building C and Building B along with other buildings (M, R, S, T & G) must be taken into consideration while designing the chillers and calculating the total load.4. The Snug Harbor campus will remain operational during construction therefore a detailedconstruction scheduling will be considered as high priority. The project is anticipated to be constructed in two (2) phases:• Phase 1 – Replacement of main chiller for cooling system located at Building L, and study/assessment of HVAC (steam and chilled water) pipe distribution system connecting from Building L to all served buildings.• Phase II – Replacement of all HVAC (cold and steam pipes) distribution system connecting from Building L to all served buildings. The exact scope of Phase II shall be determined on the assessment report submitted based on Phase I.

Ten Year Plan Category: LEGAL MANDATES AND CORRECTION OF UNSAFE CONDITIONS

Agency Project Description: The scope of work consists of providing all necessary construction management, design, andr.onstruction services required to perform ail phases of the project: Surveying, tank testing,investigation, design, construction, and construction management for the closure, removal, upgrade,or replacement of petroieum product storage tanks at various City owned sites. This work mustcomply with all local, state, nnd federal laws nnd regulations governing tanks and associated work.The general scope of work for tank replacement includes:File NYSDEC PBS application; mobilization; securing all required NYC agency approvals & permits;site survey; geophysical survey; drilling for laboratory soil and groundwater samples; crane & rigging;saw cutting; demo & disposal of old tanks, piping, and concrete vaults; dewatering· of excavation; tankbottom sludge removal & disposal; remove/transfer/dispose product; laboratory analysis of soil andgroundwater; excavate, remove, dispose incidental contaminated soil; install shoring, new tanks andtan·k sumps, piping, monitoring and leak detection system, overfill protection and alarms, electricalwiring; construction of concrete slabs and block piers; backfill excavation; resurfacing; demobilization;performance of a closeout investigation and the preparation and filing of appropriate reports;obtaining FDNY and DOB closeout documents; preparing "As-built" drawings.

FMS Project Name: Staten Island 1 and 3 Garage Construction + SOLARGR10
Agency Project Description: The Department of Sanitation of the City of New York (DSNY) is planning to develop a Staten Island Districts 1 and 3 campus that will include a new garage serving both districts and renovation of the existing Borough Repair Shop.  The site is to be reconfigured with new grading and drainage, new covered salt storage, new outdoor fueling, new household special waste collection, outdoor DSNY truck parking and a new force main sanitary line to connect to the NYC DEP sewer.

Rehabilitation includes replacement of the roof and select areas of roof drains and domes, structural work; stiffening of structural steel frame supports for new HVAC equipment, solar panels, and select parapet replacements, including fire alarm system work, and select replacement of building systems. Offices, locker rooms, and bathrooms will be phased and temporarily partitioned to allow for overhead HVAC work.
Replacement of HVAC System and Roof at Staten Island District 3 DSNY Garage and Boro Repair Shop

DSNY is planning to renovate select interior spaces of the Bureau of Building Management Central Repair Shop (BBM CRS) to provide more efficient, open plan office environmental for the Operation Assistance Unit (OAU)

Agency Project Name: Rehab of Queens District 11/13 Sanitation Garage
Agency Project Description: The Department of Sanitation of the City of New York (DSNY) is planning to rehabilitate Queens Districts 11 and 13 garage. The renovation serving both districts is to extend the useful life of the facility through rehabilitation of the building structure and systems. The renovation includes: Extensive structural work that includes the replacement of reinforced concrete slabs and stiffening of the existing steel frame, select replacement of building MEP systems, including BMS systems, architectural renovation of the entire building, study and implementation of deep energy conservation measures (DECMs), and site work which includes new landscape work and replacement of sidewalks and driveways. Rehabilitation is required to meet LEED Silver requirements.
General Rehab of Garage with exterior brick work. [No Roof work]

Replmnt & repair of combined SE outfall north 81st &19 Ave
Agency Project Name: COMBINED SEWER OUTFALL N. 81ST & 19TH AVE, LAG
Agency Project Description: The proposed project involves the reconstruction and replacement of a short length of an existing sewer and an outfall that discharges into Bowery Bay (see Figures C-4a and C-4b); this sewer and outfall reconstruction is proposed to address what is currently a partially collapsed outfall. Replacement would restore the outfall’s necessary functions and avoid a potential full collapse and failure. Specifically, the proposed project includes the following: Installation of a new a 14-foot 7-inch-wide by 8-foot-high combined sewer outfall (referenced as the Bowery Bay [BB]-005 outfall) which discharges into Bowery Bay, thereby replacing the currently collapsed outfall. The proposed outfall would be reconstructed at the same location as the existing outfall and within an existing sewer easement across land that is owned by the City of New York and under the jurisdiction of the Department of Small Business Services. The proposed sewer and outfall design calls for a reinforced concrete structure supported on a concrete cradle with a flap gate at the outlet to control any inflow of tidal water from the bay. Additionally, boulders are proposed to be installed to stabilize the bottom of the bay to minimize the potential for scour and resuspension of sediments into the water column that may otherwise occur when there is flow from the outfall. Reconstruction of a 60-foot-long by 14-foot-7-inch wide and 8-foot-high combined sewer that flows into and connects with the proposed outfall.
Ten Year Plan Category: REPLACEMENT OR AUGMENTATION OF EXISTING SYSTEMS

Replace deteriorating retain wall Pratt Av, BX  HWXPRATT
Agency Project Name: Pratt Avenue Retaining Wall and Roadway Recon
Agency Project Description: The retaining wall along the segment of Pratt Avenue (Needham Ave to Dead End) shows multiple signs of damage. This includes cracking (long cracks run the entire height of the wall) and movement of the individual elements of the wall. The cracks and movement of the wall has allowed the backfill that supports the roadway to escape. The roadway within the project limits has experienced significant damage due to settlement of supporting materials. The proposed scope includes reconstruction of the roadway and retaining wall along this segment.
Ten Year Plan Category: REPLACEMENT OR AUGMENTATION OF EXISTING SYSTEMS

Agency Project Description: Rehabilitation includes replacement of the roof and select areas of roof drains and domes, structural work; stiffening of structural steel frame supports for new HVAC equipment, solar panels, and select parapet replacements, including fire alarm system work, and select replacement of building systems. FMS Project Name: Aqueduct Restoration at Lake Street - EOH
Agency Project Name: Aqueduct Restoration at Lake Street - EOH
Agency Project Description: As a result of heavy rains and resulting runoff the Lake St. location of the Catskill Aqueduct (CA) was heavily eroded and is now in need of repairs in order to ensure the continued stability of the CA base.  The approximate location is near Lake Street, Town of Pleasantville (Station  3857+ 63).   The design and construction of this restoration and washouts are beyond the capabilities of in house staff.

The new facility will provide more space, be more centrally located to primary locations (Hillview, Croton, and JPR), reduce risk for vehicle accidents, and increased security of BWS assets.

EAST DELAWARE RELEASE CHAMBER VALVE REPLACEMENTS
Agency Project Name: Valve Replacements at East Delaware Release Chamber (EDRC)
Agency Project Description: Replacement of two (2) 42”dia cone valves and two (2) 60” butterfly valves located on the north and south line within the valve chamber of the EDRC in Downsville.  The 2 cone valves require replacement to isolate the polyjet regulating Valves.  The butterfly valves require replacement due to lack of closure & leakage.  Also included will be replacement of the Polyjet Valve Actuators and the 20” Gate Valve on the Conservation Line.  The valve replacements require the EDRC to be isolated, shutdown and bypassed.  The two (2) 42”x60” Venturi on the North & South Release Line and 12”x20” venturi on the Conservation Line are to be removed, inspected, refurbished, and reinstalled.

Agency Project Description: This project includes the demolition and replacement of four air handler units (AHUs-1, 2, 3 and 6) with four new water-sourced air handler units being installed in place, removal of 10 heat pumps with new units being installed in place and the installation of 1 plate and frame heat exchanger. Associated work includes but is not limited to wiring, electrical work, duct work and plumbing to complete the installation of the new equipment. New plate frame heat exchanger/s will be installed to protect the downstream AHUs from geothermal groundwater. Integrate the new units to the existing BCM system. An existing cooling tower will be rehabilitated and put into service. Extensive mechanical piping for the entire project is required, mainly in the mechanical rooms, although a 4” pipe loop around the exterior of the building is proposed. A new solar-heat-gain shading device is included in scope to reduce base building heat in areas with single-glazed windows. Associated architectural, structural, electrical, and plumbing work, as required. It is also to meet DCAS ACE program criteria. Temporary cooling will be needed to keep the facility operation during construction.

Agency Project Name: Renovation of Anna M. Kross Center (AMKC)  at Rikers Island
Agency Project Description: Gut renovation of existing Officers lockers and toilet and shower facilities to provide new lockers, new fixtures and interior finishes including lighting and renovated HVAC systems and other items as needed.  The flowing Officer and Senior Officer Locker Rooms will be renovated: • Locker Room Type         • Male Officer   • Female Officer               • Sr. Male Officer             • Sr. Female Officer         • Male Dep Warden         • Female Dep Warden                                                     Furthermore, the following work types have been identified:• New Lockers• Replace existing wall, floor and ceiling finishes.      • Renovate finishes in Toilet Shower Areas• Replace Plumbing Fixtures and Toilet Accessories• Replace lighting throughout with LED lighting• Renovate Ventilation/HVAC system  Justification: It was  determined that the current structures, and infrastructure that supports the buildings, located on Rikers Island requires immediate renovations and rehabilitation, and without any design and construction solutions, these structures will continue to endanger the health of the occupants.  This critical and necessary work is needed immediately to provide a safe, clean environment on Rikers Island. The renovation work proposed for the  Anna M. Kross Center (AMKC), is to address the deplorable locker room condition at this facility. The Locker room is in dire need of renovation and is long overdue. This renovation will offer a better working environment for officers which may also improve the officers moral.

FMS Project Name: Bronx Animal Care Center and Veterinary Clinic
Agency Project Description: Bronx Animal Care Center & Veterinary Clinic is a new 50,000 SF facility that will be housing admissions, adoptions, medical services, and boarding for approximately 70 dogs, 140 cats, 30 rabbits and other species to be determined. Support spaces will include spaces focused on animal caretakers & visitors including offices, restrooms, storage & areas of respite. Integrated with the architecture, the open areas on the site will include a visitor entrance plaza, courtyards to facilitate animal adoptions, enrichment & training spaces for animals, and parking for staff, visitors, and animal transportation vehicles, as well as site lighting and low-maintenance native planting throughout. In addition to the animal housing, the Bronx Animal Care Center will include a community space for academic partnership for youth and enhanced senior services. The building and associated landscape are to achieve LEED Silver standards or higher.

Agency Project Name: Green infrastructure for St. Albans Cloudburst Demonstration Project
Agency Project Description: Green infrastructure will be constructed along one block of 112th Avenue, between 177th Street and 178th Street, and along 177th Street, between Sayres Avenue and Murdock Avenue. The section on 112th will include a large, connected stormwater Greenstreet combined with underground storage via infiltration basins. The section on 177th street will include a combination of bioswales and infiltration basins. This project will include DOT-funded roadway grading and street geometry changes.

FMS Project Name: Reconst. of Beach Channel Drive-Phase B Non Sandy(QED-1030B)
Agency Project Name: Reconstruction of Beach Channel Drive -- Phase B

Agency Project Description: his project will enhance pedestrian safety and improve pedestrian circulation by constructing curb extensions, bus bulbs, missing sidewalks, and median tip extensions along Astoria Boulevard, as well as create left turn bays and crosswalks. These interventions will increase pedestrian safety, reduce conflicts between pedestrians, cars, and bikes, and improve pedestrian circulation. In addition, the capital improvements will build on the successes of the operational improvements DOT implemented within these project limits in 2016. The interventions listed below, when implemented together, will make meaningful strides towards permanent safety enhancements along this dangerous corridor in Queens. Please refer to the Context Map (pg. 9) for location references:LOCATION A• 82nd Street and Astoria Boulevardo Create a new left turnbay in addition to median tip and curb extensionso Install complex pedestrian ramp at NE corner of 82nd St and Astoria Blvdo Add bus bulb on SW corner• 83rd Ave and Astoria Boulevardo Build out of channelized area at 24th Aveo Add neckdown on 83rd St/24th AveLOCATION B• 88th Street and Astoria Boulevardo Close slip lane, expand sidewalk, add crosswalkso Median tip extension on Astoria Blvd and 88th St• 89th Street and Astoria Boulevardo Add bus bulb on south side of Astoria Blvd between 88th and 89th Streetso Add crosswalk at 25th avenue and at 89th Street• 90th Place and Astoria Boulevardo Construct missing sidewalk and install missing crosswalk• 90th Place and 25th Aveo Install missing crosswalko Possible reconstruction of sloping sidewalk at closed slip on 25th Ave in order to provide ADAaccessibility (dependent on survey)LOCATION C• 102nd Street and 29th Avenueo Widen median to ADA complianceo Construct two curb extensions on the northern side of the intersectiono Add two curb extensions at Astoria Blvd and Humphreys Street

This project will modernize the local street network in this dynamic outer-borough growth center to better meet the needs of its expanding residential population and workforce. The project scope is distributed across the following four sites in the vicinity of Court Square:A. Court Square West from Jackson Avenue to midblock (Construction of a shared street) B. Thomson Avenue from 44th Drive to Jackson Avenue (Full reconstruction, including additional public space on both the east and west sidewalks, and a raised crosswalk at the intersection with Court Square East)C. Pearson Street at Jackson Avenue (New pedestrian crossing and new curb extension for receiving ramp)D. Jackson Avenue from Court Square West to Thomson Avenue (Sidewalk reconstruction using standard materials, to eliminate the distinctive pavers along north side of Court Square Park).

This project has been initiated to bring three identified utility trenches in SI to a state of good repair. These sites, pulled from a master list, were prioritized with attention to ratings data, field observations, and community needs. The sites are split into scoping categories; full street reconstruction, and trench restoration with resurfacing. Projects will upgrade pedestrian facilities to ADA compliancy, and address adjacent capital assets in poor condition (curbs, sidewalks, and others as needed). SER002333 IS A SUB-PROJECT TO HWTRR1.
Ten Year Plan Category: TRAFFIC WORK IN CONJUNCTION WITH HIGHWAY RECONSTRUCTION

Agency Project Name: RECONSTRUCTION OF THE HENWOOD PLACE STEP STREET
Agency Project Description: RECONSTRUCTION OF THE HENWOOD PLACE STEP STREET. THIS STREET IS CURRENTLY IN STATE OF DISREPAIR AND IS SUBJECT OF FREQUENT COMPLAINTS TO DOT. THE STEPS ON HENWOOD PLACE ARE HIGHLY INEVEN DUE TO SOIL EROSION AND SINKING LANDINGS AND THE STREETS IS BESET BY SIGNIFICANT DRAINAGE ISSUES AND CHRONIC PONDING. THIS PROJECT WILL FULLY RECONSTRUCT THE HENWOOD PLACE STEP STREEET, BRINGING IT UP TO GOOD REPAIR , CREATE SAFER TRAVEL CONDITIONS .

The South Bronx Crosstown SBS capital project (BRT) will add bus pads and construct bus bulbs, curb and median extensions, and pedestrian islands for enhanced pedestrian safety and access improvements.

BRUNER & ELY IS A CRITICAL STATE OF REPAIR (SOGR) PROJECT IN THE BAYCHESTER NEIGHBORHOOD OF THE EAST BRONX. THE ROADWAYS , CURBS, AND SIDEWALKS WITHIN THE PROJECT LIMITS HAVE SUNKEN DRRAMATICALLY OVER TIME TO HEAVY VEHICLE USAGE, POOR SUBSURFACE CONDITIONS AND DEFERRED MAINTENANCE. THE PROJECT WILL BRING THESE STREETS TO STATE OF GOOD REPAIR. FURTHERMORE, THERE WILL BE STORM SEWER REPAIRS AND THE INSTALLATION OF NEW DISTRIBUTION WATERMAINS IN ALLERTON AVE. BETWEEN BRUNER AVE. AND ELY AVE.

This Vision Zero capital project will construct pedestrian safety-focused geometric improvements at threeintersections in the southern Bronx. The project scope includes two bus bulbs on Westchester Avenue below the Prospect Avenue 2/5 subway station, four additional curb extensions, and streetscape improvements. All three locations in this capital project have received successful operational treatments introduced via StreetImprovement Projects (SIPs). Capital construction will permanently improve safety conditions at theseintersections for all street users by shortening crossing distances, calming traffic, increasing pedestrian visibility, and controlling vehicle turning movements.

FMS Project Name: Pratt Ave Reconstruction and Retaining Wall, SEX20049
Agency Project Name: Pratt Avenue Retaining Wall and Roadway Recon
Agency Project Description: The retaining wall along the segment of Pratt Avenue (Needham Ave to Dead End) shows multiple signs of damage. This includes cracking (long cracks run the entire height of the wall) and movement of the individual elements of the wall. The cracks and movement of the wall has allowed the backfill that supports the roadway to escape. The roadway within the project limits has experienced significant damage due to settlement of supporting materials. The proposed scope includes reconstruction of the roadway and retaining wall along this segment.

THE JOINTS ARE IN POOR CONDITION WITH CRACKING, SPALLING AND SURROUNDING VOIDS. PORTIONS OF THE EXISTING RAILINGS ARE MISSING OR HAVE DISCONNECTED FROM THE BASE. THE PURPOSE OF THIS RECONSTRUCTION PROJECT IS TO PERFORM A REPLACEMENT-IN-KIND OF THE STEP STREET.

FMS Project Name: NEW CONSTRUCTION AT CROSSROADS JC PHASE 2.0
Agency Project Description: The scope of this project is the creation of approximately 73,320 square feet of space in a free-standing multi-level tower connected by bridges at third floor of the existing Crossroads building. The addition will house a warehouse, health care service, admission and transportation, education and vocation classrooms and workshops, and critical HVAC infrastructure to serve the new and existing facility, and miscellaneous support spaces. It is proposed the structure will be built on the south-west portion of the site.

FMS Project Name: NEW CONSTRUCTION AT HORIZON JC PHASE 2.0
Agency Project Name: NEW CONSTRUCTION HORIZON JUVENILE DETENTION CENTER
Agency Project Description: The Horizon Juvenile Detention Center Annex project consists of three phases, spread out in order to achieve minimal disruption to the operations of the existing Horizon Juvenile Center. Phase 1 – Elevated Recreation Platform and Related Work – 31,000 GSF. A new elevated recreation platform above the existing loading area without impeding on its function.  The elevated recreation platform will replace the existing recreation space designated for the construction of the Annex building. Phase 2 – Annex Building and Related Work – 75,000 GSF. A new Annex building consisting of program space to support 48 beds of housing, 8 special needs unit beds, medical, education, kitchen, and facility support. Phase 3 – At-Grade Recreation, Fencing and Related Work – 17,325 GSF. Reconfiguration of the remaining open space on the lot for additional open recreation space.

Agency Project Name: Snug Harbor Center CTR.1000 Richmond Ter.HVAC/PLU
Agency Project Description: C. MAJOR DESIGN CONSIDERATIONS1. When surveying existing conditions, special attention will be paid to current building loads, layouts, and resulting possible changes in power requirements.2. The existing chilling plant is composed of one chiller installed in approximately 1982, while one other large chiller and one small chiller are not functional. Mechanical equipment and distribution system was designed and specified as per requirement of more than 30 years ago. The centralized cooling equipment (chillers) located in Building L serve 5 other buildings – Buildings M, R, S, T & G (other buildings on site either have their own air conditioning system or use window units).3. In future phase, the Main Hall/Building C Newhouse Center for Contemporary Art and Building B-SIM Natural Sciences Collection which presently do not have any central air- conditioning system will be connected to the central cooling plant. Building C and Building B along with other buildings (M, R, S, T & G) must be taken into consideration while designing the chillers and calculating the total load.4. The Snug Harbor campus will remain operational during construction therefore a detailedconstruction scheduling will be considered as high priority. The project is anticipated to be constructed in two (2) phases:• Phase 1 – Replacement of main chiller for cooling system located at Building L, and study/assessment of HVAC (steam and chilled water) pipe distribution system connecting from Building L to all served buildings.• Phase II – Replacement of all HVAC (cold and steam pipes) distribution system connecting from Building L to all served buildings. The exact scope of Phase II shall be determined on the assessment report submitted based on Phase I.

The site is to be reconfigured with new grading and drainage, new covered salt storage, new outdoor fueling, new household special waste collection, outdoor DSNY truck parking and a new force main sanitary line to connect to the NYC DEP sewer.

Agency Project Name: Rehab of Queens District 11/13 Sanitation Garage
Agency Project Description: The Department of Sanitation of the City of New York (DSNY) is planning to rehabilitate Queens Districts 11 and 13 garage. The renovation serving both districts is to extend the useful life of the facility through rehabilitation of the building structure and systems. The renovation includes: Extensive structural work that includes the replacement of reinforced concrete slabs and stiffening of the existing steel frame, select replacement of building MEP systems, including BMS systems, architectural renovation of the entire building, study and implementation of deep energy conservation measures (DECMs), and site work which includes new landscape work and replacement of sidewalks and driveways. Rehabilitation is required to meet LEED Silver requirements.

FMS Project Name: RECON OF SANITARY SEWER, COLLIER AV(B 25 ST - BRIAR PL)
Replmnt & repair of combined SE outfall north 81st &19 Ave
Agency Project Name: COMBINED SEWER OUTFALL N. 81ST & 19TH AVE, LAG
Agency Project Description: The proposed project involves the reconstruction and replacement of a short length of an existing sewer and an outfall that discharges into Bowery Bay (see Figures C-4a and C-4b); this sewer and outfall reconstruction is proposed to address what is currently a partially collapsed outfall. Replacement would restore the outfall’s necessary functions and avoid a potential full collapse and failure. Specifically, the proposed project includes the following: Installation of a new a 14-foot 7-inch-wide by 8-foot-high combined sewer outfall (referenced as the Bowery Bay [BB]-005 outfall) which discharges into Bowery Bay, thereby replacing the currently collapsed outfall. The proposed outfall would be reconstructed at the same location as the existing outfall and within an existing sewer easement across land that is owned by the City of New York and under the jurisdiction of the Department of Small Business Services. The proposed sewer and outfall design calls for a reinforced concrete structure supported on a concrete cradle with a flap gate at the outlet to control any inflow of tidal water from the bay. Additionally, boulders are proposed to be installed to stabilize the bottom of the bay to minimize the potential for scour and resuspension of sediments into the water column that may otherwise occur when there is flow from the outfall. Reconstruction of a 60-foot-long by 14-foot-7-inch wide and 8-foot-high combined sewer that flows into and connects with the proposed outfall.
Ten Year Plan Category: REPLACEMENT OR AUGMENTATION OF EXISTING SYSTEMS

FMS Project Name: Combined SE Replacement in Davidson Avenue. Bronx (HWXS711)
Agency Project Name: RECONSTRUCTION OF STEP ST AT DAVIDSON AVE
Agency Project Description: RECONSTRUCTION OF DAVIDSON AVE STEP STREET, BRONX. THE PROJECT WILL PERFORM A REPLACEMENT-IN-KIND OF THE DAVIDSON AVE STEP ST. LOCATED AT DAVIDSON AVE BETWEEN FEATHERBED LANE AND WEST 174TH ST. THE GRANITE STEPS ARE HIGHLY UNEVEN DUE TO EROSION AND ARE AT RISK OF DESTABILIZING THE STRUCTURE. THE JOINTS ARE IN POOR CONDITION WITH CRACKING, SPALLING AND SURROUNDING VOIDS. PORTIONS OF THE EXISTING RAILINGS ARE MISSING OR HAVE DISCONNECTED FROM THE BASE. THE PURPOSE OF THIS RECONSTRUCTION PROJECT IS TO PERFORM A REPLACEMENT-IN-KIND OF THE STEP STREET.
Ten Year Plan Category: REPLACEMENT OR AUGMENTATION OF EXISTING SYSTEMS

Replace deteriorating retain wall Pratt Av, BX  HWXPRATT
Agency Project Name: Pratt Avenue Retaining Wall and Roadway Recon
Agency Project Description: The retaining wall along the segment of Pratt Avenue (Needham Ave to Dead End) shows multiple signs of damage. This includes cracking (long cracks run the entire height of the wall) and movement of the individual elements of the wall. The cracks and movement of the wall has allowed the backfill that supports the roadway to escape. The roadway within the project limits has experienced significant damage due to settlement of supporting materials. The proposed scope includes reconstruction of the roadway and retaining wall along this segment.
Ten Year Plan Category: REPLACEMENT OR AUGMENTATION OF EXISTING SYSTEMS

FMS Project Name: Aqueduct Restoration at Lake Street - EOH
Agency Project Name: Aqueduct Restoration at Lake Street - EOH
Agency Project Description: As a result of heavy rains and resulting runoff the Lake St. location of the Catskill Aqueduct (CA) was heavily eroded and is now in need of repairs in order to ensure the continued stability of the CA base.  The approximate location is near Lake Street, Town of Pleasantville (Station  3857+ 63).   The design and construction of this restoration and washouts are beyond the capabilities of in house staff.

FMS Project Name: EAST DELAWARE RELEASE CHAMBER VALVE REPLACEMENTS
Agency Project Name: Valve Replacements at East Delaware Release Chamber (EDRC)
Agency Project Description: Replacement of two (2) 42”dia cone valves and two (2) 60” butterfly valves located on the north and south line within the valve chamber of the EDRC in Downsville.  The 2 cone valves require replacement to isolate the polyjet regulating Valves.  The butterfly valves require replacement due to lack of closure & leakage.  Also included will be replacement of the Polyjet Valve Actuators and the 20” Gate Valve on the Conservation Line.  The valve replacements require the EDRC to be isolated, shutdown and bypassed.  The two (2) 42”x60” Venturi on the North & South Release Line and 12”x20” venturi on the Conservation Line are to be removed, inspected, refurbished, and reinstalled.

Agency Project Description: Replacement of Shore (Belt) Parkway Bridge over Mill Basin, Brooklyn.The project consists of the removal of the existing fourteen (14) span bascule bridge (length 864 feet) and replacement with a seventeen (17) span fixed bridge (length 2,645 feet) elevated to provide a 60 foot vertical clearance over the navigational channel. The typical bridge section consists of a composite concrete deck and steel superstructure supported on a reinforced concrete substructure on concrete piles. The new bridge will be constructed on a new alignment set on the north side of the existing bridge, partially overlapping with the existing bridge. The new bridge and approach roadways will provide three (3) 12 foot wide lanes for vehicular traffic, a 12 foot wide right shoulder on the bridge and a 10 foot wide right shoulder on the approach roadways, a minimum 4 foot wide left shoulder in each direction, and a 12 foot wide bicycle / pedestrian facility adjacent to the eastbound roadway. Substandard stopping sight distance for the bridge and approach roadways will be eliminated.  The design speed for the bridge and approach roadways is 60 MPH (100 KMPH). Necessary upland and wetland mitigation work will be performed.
